Every New England Road Trip Requires a BBQ Plate From B.T.'s Smokehouse | Bon Appétit

These days, I take field trips to Sturbridge to eat at B.T.'s Smokehouse, an unassuming roadside restaurant serving some of the best barbecue I've ever eaten, despite being in a region that’s, well, not known for barbecue.Situated between I-84 and I-90, B.T.’s is an ideal pit stop for any drive that takes you up to (or down from) Boston, New Hampshire, or Maine. Brisket is the thing here—smoked for 24 to 30 hours on local apple and hickory wood. You can order it à la carte, in a Reuben-style sandwich, or—my favorite—on a platter with classic sides like collard greens and mac and cheese.While it may be unassuming, B.T.’s is hardly undiscovered. The lines get long, so time your trip to hit the smokehouse when it opens at 11 a.m. or during the late-afternoon lull. Order your meat to go, grab a beer at the convenience store next door, and park yourself on the hood of your car, the curb, or anywhere you can find a spot. It isn’t glamorous, but it is astonishingly good.Go there: B.T.’s SmokehouseExplore Bon AppétitHighly RecommendRestaurantsBarbecueNew EnglandRecipes you want to make. Cooking advice that works.
